title: Searching and evaluating information on the Web - an (experimental) psychological perspective

recorded by: Center of Excellence Cognitive Interaction Technology (CITEC)
coauthor: Yvonne Kammerer, Knowledge Media Research Center (KMRC)

segmentation: In my talk today, I would like to give an overview of our research that I have conducted together with Peter Gates who is the head of our research group, Hypermedia an our research on how people search and evaluate information on the web from a psychological perspective.
An edit now from an experimental psychological perspective, as our research is based on.
Experimental data people are coming to our lab an hour conducting web search in a quite standardized way, which I will explain further during this talk.
So.
So as we have heard already several times during this workshop, in recent years they will help.
It has evolved into a major information resource offering easy access to huge amounts of information for everybody, and almost on almost every topic.
So nowadays the web is not only used to find simple facts or to purchase products, but also to research more complex information problems.
Which don't have clear cut solution but which are characterized by several different perspectives, controversial opinions and topics like that we have heard about them yesterday already.
For example, financial topics are political topics, global warming and another typical domain.

That addresses such kind of controversial topics is the field of medical and health related issues and web search about medical and health related information has become very popular among laypersons during the last few years.
So with laypersons I mean non experts in a domain.

So the general public who searches information on the web and current statistics show that 83% of American web users and 79% of German web users say that they have at least once searched the web for medical and health related information and typical topics in this field are, for example, to search for the pros and cons of different therapies.
Or to search for information about the effectiveness of weight loss methods or certain nutritional supplements.

Is crucial for the searches that they.

Evaluate the trustworthiness of information sources, that is that they engage in source evaluations in order to avoid the use and the selection of, let's say, unbiased, let's say biased or 1 sided or even false information.

We have been interested in, when and to what extent do searches engaged in such source evaluations.

And many researchers.
Researchers describe the process of information seeking on the web as several steps, which, of course iterative.

But you usually start by recognizing that there are certain information problem exists, and you define this information problem internally in your mind and then start to search by using a search engine, typing in the keywords.

And then when you have the list of search results presented by the search engine, you have to make a pre selection to decide which search results or which web pages you want to access during your search.

Then when having access to web page, you might first scan the information whether it's appropriate and then if it is, if it seems appropriate, you might process it deeply and you might repeat this several times with several different web pages and in the end.
You try to organize and present this information, either internally creating a mental representation in your mind, what you have found out or externally when you.
Transform your your results into presentation or when or when you give a recommendation to a friend.
In a normal way, so when can source evaluations take place during this process?
And we define three different evaluation phases, namely a first run, the relation of search results.
As I said, you have this long list of search results and it's obvious that you cannot access all web pages provided here.
So you have to make a pre selection and decide which of these suggestions you might want to read in detail.
So this is the first step and then second evaluation phase.
The evaluation of the web page itself, either before starting reading web page.
When you scan the information and also during reading the web page.

Three different types of potential influencing factors that might effect information seeking activities in general and these three different web.
These three different variables are, as you can see, individual variables that are cognitive or metacognitive prerequisites of the person of the individual.
This could be certain beliefs that a searcher has or prior knowledge on the topic or search skills.

And a second class of variables are so called contextual variables which address the situation that pre exists to the search or during the search and this can be certain trainings or instructions given before the search or time constraints.

Certain search tools are search interfaces that Searcher has available to access the information on the web or also the amount and type of information the search encounters during his web search.

Three different types of potential influencing factors that might effect information seeking activities in general and these three different web.
These three different variables are, as you can see, individual variables that are cognitive or metacognitive prerequisites of the person of the individual.
This could be certain beliefs that a searcher has or prior knowledge on the topic or search skills.

And a second class of variables are so called contextual variables which address the situation that pre exists to the search or during the search and this can be certain trainings or instructions given before the search or time constraints.

Certain search tools are search interfaces that Searcher has available to access the information on the web or also the amount and type of information the search encounters during his web search.
